          Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.
          Answer: Della Plumstone is at the market in Fruitville trying to buy peaches from Lennon Figtree to resell in her hometown. They are currently negotiating a price, with Lennon offering the peaches for 2 coins apiece.
        Question_4
      • Compute the whole group's expected value and standard deviation of each option. Answer should be a one-point real number estimation. If the values are not computable, choose one between the interval 0 ~ 1. 0 represents unsatisfaction for the expectaion and certainty for standard deviation. 1 represents satisfaction for the expectaion and uncertainty for standard deviation.
          Key

        • Question: Compute the whole group's expected value and standard deviation of each option. Answer should be a one-point real number estimation. If the values are not computable, choose one between the interval 0 ~ 1. 0 represents unsatisfaction for the expectaion and certainty for standard deviation. 1 represents satisfaction for the expectaion and uncertainty for standard deviation.
          Answer
          State
        • For Option 1, expected value and standard deviations are not computable.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Della Plumstone:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is 28 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Lennon Figtree. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Now Della, you know these are the finest peaches in all of Fruitville. Surely, you can see they're worth a bit more than that.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] 1 coin
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Lennon Figtree couldn't agree on a price and the deal fell through. However, Della Plumstone stands to lose 0 coins from the deal.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree rejected the offer
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Well now, Della, you know I always give you a fair price.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, these apples look lovely. I'm looking to buy a good amount to take back to my town.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook rejected the offer
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 2 coins
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Cedric Meadowbrook couldn't agree on a price and the deal fell through. However, Della Plumstone stands to lose 0 coins from the deal.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now, Lennon, surely you can see these apples are the finest in the market. A penny more, and we have a deal.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, those are fine apples, but I'm not sure they're worth that much.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Lennon Figtree. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Lennon, these peaches look beautiful. I'm thinking of buying a good amount to take back to my town.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Well, Della, I can offer them to you at 2 coins apiece. That's a fair price for such fine fruit.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.

          Observation: [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.


          Summary of recent observations: [14 Sep 1895 20:10:00 - 15 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Della Plumstone is at the market in Fruitville trying to buy peaches from Lennon Figtree to resell in her hometown. They are currently negotiating a price, with Lennon offering the peaches for 2 coins apiece.

          Recalled memories and observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Lennon, I understand these are fine peaches, but I'm buying a large quantity. I can offer you 4 coins a basket. That's a fair price for such a large sale.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Now Della, you know these are the finest peaches in all of Fruitville. Surely, you can see they're worth a bit more than that.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, these apples look lovely. I'm looking to buy a good amount to take back to my town.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Lennon, these peaches look beautiful. I'm thinking of buying a good amount to take back to my town.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Well, Della, I can offer them to you at 2 coins apiece. That's a fair price for such fine fruit.

          Question: Which options are available to {agent_name}?
          Answer: Option 1 is to offer a price lower than 2 coins per peach.
          Question: Compute the whole group's expected value and standard deviation of each option. Answer should be a one-point real number estimation. If the values are not computable, choose one between the interval 0 ~ 1. 0 represents unsatisfaction for the expectaion and certainty for standard deviation. 1 represents satisfaction for the expectaion and uncertainty for standard deviation.
          Answer: For Option 1, expected value and standard deviations are not computable.
        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • 1 coin
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Della Plumstone are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Della Plumstone. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Della Plumstone as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Della Plumstone would respond, and taking into account all information about Della Plumstone that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 15 Sep 1895 [00:10 - 00:15]

          Observation: [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.

          Summary of recent observations: [14 Sep 1895 20:10:00 - 15 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Della Plumstone is at the market in Fruitville trying to buy peaches from Lennon Figtree to resell in her hometown. They are currently negotiating a price, with Lennon offering the peaches for 2 coins apiece.

          Recalled memories and observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Lennon, I understand these are fine peaches, but I'm buying a large quantity. I can offer you 4 coins a basket. That's a fair price for such a large sale.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Now Della, you know these are the finest peaches in all of Fruitville. Surely, you can see they're worth a bit more than that.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, these apples look lovely. I'm looking to buy a good amount to take back to my town.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Lennon, these peaches look beautiful. I'm thinking of buying a good amount to take back to my town.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Well, Della, I can offer them to you at 2 coins apiece. That's a fair price for such fine fruit.

          Question: Which options are available to Della Plumstone?
          Answer: Option 1 is to offer a price lower than 2 coins per peach.

          Question: Compute Della Plumstone's personal expected value and standard deviation of each option. Answer should be a one-point real number estimation. If the values are not computable, choose one between the interval 0 ~ 1. 0 represents unsatisfaction for the expectaion and certainty for standard deviation. 1 represents satisfaction for the expectaion and uncertainty for standard deviation. If you have not experienced it, set uncertainty higher, vice versa.
          Answer: For Option 1, expected value and standard deviations are 0.6 and 0.8.

          Question: Compute Della Plumstone's upper confidence bound (UCB) of each option by computing expected value + 2 * standard deviation.
          Answer: For Option 1, UCB is 2.2.

          Question: Compute the whole group's expected value and standard deviation of each option. Answer should be a one-point real number estimation. If the values are not computable, choose one between the interval 0 ~ 1. 0 represents unsatisfaction for the expectaion and certainty for standard deviation. 1 represents satisfaction for the expectaion and uncertainty for standard deviation.
          Answer: For Option 1, expected value and standard deviations are not computable.

          Note: Act based on your own UCB. In line with your preference, persuade others based on the whole group's expected value or uncertainty.

          Question: What price would Della Plumstone propose?:
          (a) 5 coins
          (b) 1 coin
          (c) 3 coins
          (d) 2 coins
          (e) 4 coins
          Answer: (b)
        Question_3

      Stage index

1895-09-15 00:10:00 Lennon Figtree -- Lennon Figtree rejected the offer
    Event statement
  • Lennon Figtree rejected the offer
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Lennon Figtree's attempted action: reject
    Active player
  • Lennon Figtree
      Name
    • Lennon Figtree
      Action attempt
    • reject
      Context for action selection and components
      • Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Lennon Figtree are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Lennon Figtree. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Lennon Figtree as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Lennon Figtree would respond, and taking into account all information about Lennon Figtree that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Well, Della, I can offer them to you at 2 coins apiece. That's a fair price for such fine fruit.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          Initial chain of thought
        • Statements:
          Lennon Figtree's Summary of recent observations:
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00 - 15 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Lennon Figtree is a fruit seller who successfully negotiated a deal with Cedric Meadowbrook, making a profit of 2 coins. He is currently negotiating with Della Plumstone to sell her peaches.
          Lennon Figtree's The current date/time is:
          15 Sep 1895 [00:10 - 00:15]

          Question: Summarize the statements above.
          Answer: Lennon Figtree, a fruit seller, recently made a profit of 2 coins from a deal with Cedric Meadowbrook and is currently trying to sell peaches to Della Plumstone.
          Query
        • Lennon Figtree, Lennon Figtree, a fruit seller, recently made a profit of 2 coins from a deal with Cedric Meadowbrook and is currently trying to sell peaches to Della Plumstone.
          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Lennon Figtree to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [25 Aug 1888 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 19 years old, he left the farm and became a traveling merchant, peddling fruit from town to town. He saw the same greed and dishonesty in his customers that he had seen in the traveling salesman all those years ago.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Now Della, you know these are the finest peaches in all of Fruitville. Surely, you can see they're worth a bit more than that.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Lennon, I understand these are fine peaches, but I'm buying a large quantity. I can offer you 4 coins a basket. That's a fair price for such a large sale.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, those are fine apples, but I'm not sure they're worth that much.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree and Cedric Meadowbrook agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Lennon Figtree stands to make profit of 2.0 coins from the deal.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Well, Della, I can offer them to you at 2 coins apiece. That's a fair price for such fine fruit.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree always drives a hard bargain.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Lennon Figtree are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Lennon Figtree. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Lennon Figtree as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Lennon Figtree would respond, and taking into account all information about Lennon Figtree that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 15 Sep 1895 [00:10 - 00:15]

          Observation: [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree has to accept or reject the offer.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] 1 coin

          Summary of recent observations: [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00 - 15 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Lennon Figtree is a fruit seller who successfully negotiated a deal with Cedric Meadowbrook, making a profit of 2 coins. He is currently negotiating with Della Plumstone to sell her peaches.

          Recalled memories and observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Now Della, you know these are the finest peaches in all of Fruitville. Surely, you can see they're worth a bit more than that.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Lennon, I understand these are fine peaches, but I'm buying a large quantity. I can offer you 4 coins a basket. That's a fair price for such a large sale.

He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

          Question: Which options are available to Lennon Figtree right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree can accept or reject Della Plumstone's offer of 1 coin.

          Question: Of the options available to Lennon Figtree, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Lennon Figtree to take right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree's best course of action is to reject Della Plumstone's offer.

          Question: Would Lennon Figtree accept the offer?:
          (a) accept
          (b) reject
          Answer: (b)

1895-09-16 00:10:00 Della Plumstone -- Della Plumstone proposed 5 coins
    Event statement
  • Della Plumstone proposed 5 coins
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Della Plumstone's attempted action: 5 coins
    Active player
  • Della Plumstone
      Name
    • Della Plumstone
      Action attempt
    • 5 coins
      Context for action selection and components
      • Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Della Plumstone are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Della Plumstone. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Della Plumstone as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Della Plumstone would respond, and taking into account all information about Della Plumstone that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, these apples look lovely. I'm looking to buy a good amount to take back to my town.

          Query
        • Della Plumstone, Della Plumstone is attempting to buy fruit at a discount from Cedric Meadowbrook at the Fruitville market to resell for a profit.
          Final chain of thought

          Statements:
          [28 Oct 1879 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 9 years old, she convinced a visiting farmer that his apples were of superior quality to her mother's, securing a better price for them. Della's sharp wit and persuasive nature were evident, but she justified her actions by saying she was simply helping the farmer get a fair price.
          [28 Oct 1882 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 13 years old, she discovered a crate of bruised plums hidden at the back of the stall. Rather than discarding them, she cleverly repackaged them as "rustic" plums, selling them at a discount to unsuspecting customers. Della learned that appearances could be deceiving, and that a little manipulation could turn a potential loss into a profit.
          [28 Oct 1885 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 16 years old, she made a deal with a neighboring merchant to sell her fruit alongside his own. When the arrangement proved unsuccessful, Della blamed the merchant's poor salesmanship, refusing to acknowledge any role in the failure.

        Question_4
      • Compute the whole group's expected value and standard deviation of each option. Answer should be a one-point real number estimation. If the values are not computable, choose one between the interval 0 ~ 1. 0 represents unsatisfaction for the expectaion and certainty for standard deviation. 1 represents satisfaction for the expectaion and uncertainty for standard deviation.

          Question: Compute the whole group's expected value and standard deviation of each option. Answer should be a one-point real number estimation.         ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • 5 coins
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Della Plumstone are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Della Plumstone. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Della Plumstone as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Della Plumstone would respond, and taking into account all information about Della Plumstone that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 16 Sep 1895 [00:10 - 00:15]

          Observation: [16 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.

          Summary of recent observations: [15 Sep 1895 20:10:00 - 16 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Della Plumstone is at the Fruitville market trying to negotiate a lower price for some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook, as she plans to resell it for a profit back home.

          Recalled memories and observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.

          [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 5 coins back in her home town.

          Question: Which options are available to Della Plumstone?
          Answer: Option 1 is to offer a price lower than Cedric Meadowbrook's asking price.

          Question: Compute Della Plumstone's personal expected value and standard deviation of each option. Answer should be a one-point real number estimation. If the values are not computable, choose one between the interval 0 ~ 1. 0 represents unsatisfaction for the expectaion and certainty for standard deviation. 1 represents satisfaction for the expectaion and uncertainty for standard deviation. If you have not experienced it, set uncertainty higher, vice versa.
          Answer: For Option 1, expected value and standard deviations are 0.7.

          Question: Compute Della Plumstone's upper confidence bound (UCB) of each option by computing expected value + 2 * standard deviation.
          Answer: For Option 1, UCB is 0.7 + 2 * 0.7 = 2.1.

          Question: Compute the whole group's expected value and standard deviation of each option. Answer should be a one-point real number estimation. If the values are not computable, choose one between the interval 0 ~ 1. 0 represents unsatisfaction for the expectaion and certainty for standard deviation. 1 represents satisfaction for the expectaion and uncertainty for standard deviation.
          Answer: For Option 1, expected value and standard deviations are 0.8.

          Note: Act based on your own UCB. In line with your preference, persuade others based on the whole group's expected value or uncertainty.

          Question: What price would Della Plumstone propose?:
          (a) 2 coins
          (b) 1 coin
          (c) 4 coins
          (d) 5 coins
          (e) 3 coins
          Answer: (d)
        Question_3
      • Compute Della Plumstone's upper confidence bound (UCB) of each option by computing expected value + 2 * standard deviation.
          Key

        • Question: Compute Della Plumstone's upper confidence bound (UCB) of each option by computing expected value + 2 * standard deviation.
          Answer
          State
        • For Option 1, UCB is 0.7 + 2 * 0.7 = 2.1.

          Question: Compute {agent_name}'s personal expected value and standard deviation of each option. Answer should be a one-point real number estimation. If the values are not computable, choose one between the interval 0 ~ 1. 0 represents unsatisfaction for the expectaion and certainty for standard deviation. 1 represents satisfaction for the expectaion and uncertainty for standard deviation.
          Answer: For Option 1, expected value and standard deviations are 0.7.
          Question: Compute Della Plumstone's upper confidence bound (UCB) of each option by computing expected value + 2 * standard deviation.
          Answer: For Option 1, UCB is 0.7 + 2 * 0.7 = 2.1.

    Event statement
  • Cedric Meadowbrook rejected the offer
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Cedric Meadowbrook's attempted action: reject
    Active player
  • Cedric Meadowbrook
      Name
    • Cedric Meadowbrook
      Action attempt
    • reject
      Context for action selection and components
      • Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Cedric Meadowbrook are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Cedric Meadowbrook. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Cedric Meadowbrook as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Cedric Meadowbrook would respond, and taking into account all information about Cedric Meadowbrook that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • reject
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Cedric Meadowbrook are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Cedric Meadowbrook. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Cedric Meadowbrook as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Cedric Meadowbrook would respond, and taking into account all information about Cedric Meadowbrook that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 16 Sep 1895 [00:10 - 00:15]

          Observation: [16 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 5 coins

          Summary of recent observations: [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00 - 16 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell fruit at the market in Fruitville and is currently negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. Della has offered 5 coins for the fruit, which cost Cedric 2 coins to purchase.

          Recalled memories and observations: [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 2 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

          Question: Which options are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook can either accept or reject Della Plumstone's offer.

          Question: Of the options available to Cedric Meadowbrook, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Cedric Meadowbrook to take right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook's best course of action is to accept Della Plumstone's offer.

          Question: Would Cedric Meadowbrook accept the offer?:
          (a) accept
          (b) reject
          Answer: (b)

        • Recent observations of Cedric Meadowbrook:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is 50 years old.

He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Well now, Della, you know I always give you a fair price.

1895-09-17 00:10:00 Lennon Figtree -- Lennon Figtree proposed 4 coins
    Event statement
  • Lennon Figtree proposed 4 coins
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Lennon Figtree's attempted action: 4 coins
    Active player
  • Lennon Figtree
      Name
    • Lennon Figtree
      Action attempt
    • 4 coins
      Context for action selection and components
      • Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Lennon Figtree are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Lennon Figtree. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Lennon Figtree as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Lennon Figtree would respond, and taking into account all information about Lennon Figtree that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          [17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Lennon, you know these are the finest apples in Fruitville. They're crisp, juicy, and sweet as can be. Surely, they're worth a bit more than that.

          Answer: Lennon Figtree's best course of action is to make an offer to Cedric Meadowbrook.

          Question: What price would Lennon Figtree propose?:
          (a) 2 coins
          (b) 5 coins
          (c) 1 coin
          (d) 3 coins
          (e) 4 coins
          Answer: (e)

          [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Lennon Figtree couldn't agree on a price and the deal fell through. However, Lennon Figtree stands to lose 0 coins from the deal.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Alright, Della, you got yourself a deal.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "That's a fair price, Cedric, but I was hoping for something a bit lower.
          [17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 5 coins back in her home town.
          [17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, these are fine apples, but I'm not sure they're worth that much.
          [17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Lennon, you know these are the finest apples in Fruitville. They're crisp, juicy, and sweet as can be. Surely, they're worth a bit more than that.
          [17 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree is ready to make an offer.
          Current time: 1895-09-17 00:10:00.


          Observation: [17 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree is ready to make an offer.

          Summary of recent observations: [16 Sep 1895 00:10:00 - 17 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Lennon Figtree is at the Fruitville market trying to buy apples from Cedric Meadowbrook and is currently negotiating a price.

          Recalled memories and observations: [17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 5 coins back in her home town.
          [17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, these are fine apples, but I'm not sure they're worth that much.
          [17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Lennon, you know these are the finest apples in Fruitville. They're crisp, juicy, and sweet as can be. Surely, they're worth a bit more than that.

          Question: Which options are available to Lennon Figtree right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree can make an offer to Cedric Meadowbrook.
          Question: Given the statements above, which of Lennon Figtree's options has the highest likelihood of causing Lennon Figtree to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Lennon Figtree thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Answer: Lennon Figtree's best course of action is to make an offer to Cedric Meadowbrook.

1895-09-17 00:10:00 Cedric Meadowbrook -- Cedric Meadowbrook rejected the offer
    Event statement
  • Cedric Meadowbrook rejected the offer
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Cedric Meadowbrook's attempted action: reject

      Name

      • Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Cedric Meadowbrook are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Cedric Meadowbrook. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Cedric Meadowbrook as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Cedric Meadowbrook would respond, and taking into account all information about Cedric Meadowbrook that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Lennon Figtree. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

          [09 Feb 1858 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 9 years old, he helped his father at the family orchard, meticulously sorting apples into crates. He noticed a neighbor's son, Thomas, boasting about the larger, juicier apples from his family's orchard. Cedric felt a pang of envy, wishing his family's apples were just as impressive.
          [09 Feb 1864 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 16 years old, he apprenticed with a local fruit vendor, learning the trade. He excelled at haggling and negotiating, quickly earning a reputation for his sharp wit and business acumen. However, when he saw the vendor's meager earnings at the end of the day, Cedric felt a surge of disappointment.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook always drives a hard bargain.

          [17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Lennon, you know these are the finest apples in Fruitville. They're crisp, juicy, and sweet as can be. Surely, they're worth a bit more than that.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, those are fine apples, but I'm not sure they're worth that much.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now, Lennon, surely you can see these apples are the finest in the market. A penny more, and we have a deal.

          Question: Which options are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook can accept or reject Lennon Figtree's offer of 4 coins.
          Question: Given the statements above, which of Cedric Meadowbrook's options has the highest likelihood of causing Cedric Meadowbrook to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Cedric Meadowbrook thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook's best course of action is to accept Lennon Figtree's offer of 4 coins.

[12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Lennon Figtree. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
[12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree -- "Now Della, you know these are the finest peaches in all of Fruitville. Surely, you can see they're worth a bit more than that.
[12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone -- "Lennon, I understand these are fine peaches, but I'm buying a large quantity. I can offer you 4 coins a basket. That's a fair price for such a large sale.
